Markdown Content:
! Image 1: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife. com https://thewoksoflife.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/big-pot-chicken-8.jpg) For readers who’ve been to or lived in some parts of China, a big dish of “big plate chicken” 大盘鸡, da pan ji is like coming home.

0-chunk_2_-8964668118671877362.chunk_text: For readers who’ve been to or lived in some parts of China, a big dish of “big plate chicken” 大盘鸡, da pan ji is like coming home. It’s one of those dishes that has caught on like wildfire in larger Chinese cities, and many restaurants have added it to their menus. This Chinese chicken stew recipe originated in the Xinjiang, China http://amzn.to/2CIhnxr) where bold and tasty spices are used like in our Xinjiang Fried Chicken https://thewoksoflife.com/2014/05/fried-chicken-w-xinjiang-spices/ "Fried Chicken w/ Xinjiang Spices" . 大盘鸡, da pan ji also has a special place in my heart, because it makes me miss China—especially all that wonderful food.

0-chunk_3_8121756373863670329.chunk_text: 大盘鸡, da pan ji also has a special place in my heart, because it makes me miss China—especially all that wonderful food. We’re all reminiscing about it these days—the ability to just walk out of the apartment, hail a cab for 3 bucks, and have a big, wonderful meal for 20 30 bucks. You can’t beat it. I’m not going to lie, authentic big plate chicken should probably be cooked with a whole chicken, cut into small pieces with bones and skin still intact.

0-chunk_4_3920739040354387993.chunk_text: I’m not going to lie, authentic big plate chicken should probably be cooked with a whole chicken, cut into small pieces with bones and skin still intact. That’s how it’s made in restaurants in China, and it’s a well known fact that Asians love to gnaw on bones plus, meat on the bone tends to be more tender and juicier . I’ve decided not to put you through that whole chicken preparation process, so we’re going to use the next best thing: boneless chicken thighs. I think the brilliance of “big plate chicken”is in the noodles at the bottom of the plate, which soak up all the wonderful sauce.

0-chunk_5_2521213155303546758.chunk_text:
I think the brilliance of “big plate chicken”is in the noodles at the bottom of the plate, which soak up all the wonderful sauce. We hope you and your families will enjoy this truly wonderful one plate meal! You’ll need: Big Plate Chicken: Recipe Instructions
!

! Image 2: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife. com blob:http://localhost/4f36ea15608fb2de9bc2113ee080a2ea)! Image 3: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife. com blob:http://localhost/c9e1b799a43ec0cfef6f39bf86f0c12f)

0-chunk_7_-4159197845414476959.chunk_text: com blob:http://localhost/c9e1b799a43ec0cfef6f39bf86f0c12f) Start by marinating the chicken. Cut the chicken thighs into bite sized pieces and transfer to a bowl with the light soy sauce https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/), sesame oil https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#sesame-oil), shaoxing wine https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#shaoxing), and cornstarch https://thewoksoflife.com/rice-grains-and-flours/#cornstarch). Set aside for 20 minutes while you prep the rest of the ingredients. When you’re ready to cook, heat the oil in a wok https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to/chinese-cooking-tools/)over low heat.

0-chunk_8_4592439974674219496.chunk_text:
When you’re ready to cook, heat the oil in a wok https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to/chinese-cooking-tools/)over low heat. Add the star anise https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#star-anise), cinnamon stick https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#gui-pi), bay leaves https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#bay-leaf), ginger https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#ginger), garlic https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#garlic), Sichuan peppercorns https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#sichuan-peppercorn), whole dried red chilies https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#red-dried-chili-peppers), and sugar. Cook this mixture for 2 minutes, making sure they don’t burn.
! Image 4: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife.

0-chunk_10_1224937437648026552.chunk_text:
Add the chicken and turn up the heat. Stir fry until the chicken is seared.
! Image 6: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife. com blob:http://localhost/9e1eb0ced114e47c024b2a11ba6c4fb2)

0-chunk_11_-3335584450215447868.chunk_text: com blob:http://localhost/9e1eb0ced114e47c024b2a11ba6c4fb2) Add the potatoes and carrots and stir fry for a minute. Then add the dark soy sauce https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#dark-soy-sauce), light soy sauce https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/), Shaoxing wine https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#shaoxing), and 3 cups water. Bring to a boil and reduce the heat to medium.

0-chunk_12_-3757641307309285378.chunk_text: Bring to a boil and reduce the heat to medium. Cover the wok and cook for 15 minutes, until the potatoes are tender. While the chicken is cooking, bring a pot of water to a boil. Follow the package instructions to cook the dried noodle https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-noodles-wrappers/) of your choice preferably a thicker style flat noodle https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-noodles-wrappers/#knife-sliced-noodles)). Drain.

0-chunk_13_5915949363680835954.chunk_text: Follow the package instructions to cook the dried noodle https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-noodles-wrappers/) of your choice preferably a thicker style flat noodle https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-noodles-wrappers/#knife-sliced-noodles)). Drain. Once the potatoes are cooked through, by now, there should be at least 1 – 1 1/2 cup of liquid in the wok, so add more water if needed. To your wok, stir in the bell peppers. Cover and simmer for another 5 minutes.

0-chunk_14_8995188255897608321.chunk_text:
Cover and simmer for another 5 minutes. Add the scallions https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/), and season with salt to taste.
! Image 7: Big Plate Chicken Chinese Da Pan Ji with Noodles, by thewoksoflife. com blob:http://localhost/dd9cf96aac438c09a903d30518987df7)

If the sauce is too thin, just turn up the heat to reduce and thicken the sauce. Now transfer the noodles to a large plate, and cover with your chicken and vegetables.

0-chunk_16_-748480617842155079.chunk_text:
Now transfer the noodles to a large plate, and cover with your chicken and vegetables. Sprinkle with scallions and serve immediately!

Title: Smashed Asian Cucumber Salad URL Source: https://thewoksoflife.com/smashed-asian-cucumber-salad Published Time: 2022 09 02T14:40:00 00:00 Markdown Content:
!

1-chunk_1_-8622715761480764852.chunk_text:
Markdown Content:
! Image 1: Smashed Asian Cucumber Salad https://thewoksoflife.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/smashed-asian-cucumber-salad-5.jpg) This Smashed Asian cucumber salad recipe is one of our most popular recipes for a reason! It’s light, refreshing and easy to make in just 10 minutes.

1-chunk_2_-5944939801450436837.chunk_text: It’s light, refreshing and easy to make in just 10 minutes. It’s also packed with flavor from a zingy dressing, garlic, and cilantro. Note: This recipe was originally published in June 2015. We’ve since updated it with higher resolution images, clearer instructions, a YouTube video showing how to make it, and metric measurements.

1-chunk_3_964426833724413541.chunk_text: We’ve since updated it with higher resolution images, clearer instructions, a YouTube video showing how to make it, and metric measurements. The recipe remains the same. Enjoy! The Benefits of Cucumber

1-chunk_4_-8522708269588279062.chunk_text: The Benefits of Cucumber In our family, I’m the resident whacky Chinese medicine enthusiast. I drink the elixirs check out Sarah’s experience from way back when here https://thewoksoflife.com/2013/06/the-joys-of-drinking-rancid-bark-juice/ "THE JOYS OF DRINKING RANCID BARK JUICE" , do acupuncture, read the most books, and enjoy the healing powers of a good Chinese foot massage. So I’ll start this recipe by saying, everyone knows that cucumber salad is a great summer dish.

1-chunk_5_6131145440651607139.chunk_text: So I’ll start this recipe by saying, everyone knows that cucumber salad is a great summer dish. But do you know about its health benefits? According to TCM Traditional Chinese Medicine , cucumber cleanses and detoxifies, it helps reduce high blood pressure, and, with its “cooling” element, also eases the internal heat of the body. In short,eat plenty of cucumber when it’s in season!

1-chunk_6_1011131806280418569.chunk_text: In short,eat plenty of cucumber when it’s in season! In the U. S. , you might find a Greek salad, a dill pickle here and there, and perhaps a pitcher of cucumber water.

1-chunk_7_-6799623667451313288.chunk_text: , you might find a Greek salad, a dill pickle here and there, and perhaps a pitcher of cucumber water. But people in China take eating cucumbers to a whole new level. For example, we Americans would probably enjoy an ice cream cone or gnaw on a turkey leg if you’re at Disney World when visiting a park or a zoo. But in China, you can see people crunching on cucumbers as they walk around, ride the train, or take a rest on the Great Wall.

1-chunk_8_-7092429136320506534.chunk_text: But in China, you can see people crunching on cucumbers as they walk around, ride the train, or take a rest on the Great Wall. It’s an everywhere, anytime snack. Fruit peddlers peel them for you and they’re only RMB 1. 00 15 cents at the time of this writing a piece.

1-chunk_9_-8464280280934224259.chunk_text: 00 15 cents at the time of this writing a piece. A bargain! This Asian cucumber salad is also a popular appetizer/cold dish 凉菜 on most restaurant menus. Not only is it so easy to whip up, it’s crunchy, crispy, and healthy.

1-chunk_10_4253542987305680171.chunk_text:
Not only is it so easy to whip up, it’s crunchy, crispy, and healthy. We make this on a weekly basis when we have cucumbers in the garden, because it’s so simple and refreshing!
! Image 2: Chinese cucumber salad blob:http://localhost/959adaf9159bdd7d987f52b44327304c) The Smashing Technique

1-chunk_11_-7772182304201461453.chunk_text: The Smashing Technique The key to this salad is to smash the cucumbers with a heavy cleaver or rolling pin . This method creates lots of jagged edges for the tasty dressing to cling to. This method is common in China!

1-chunk_12_4697642394116701134.chunk_text: This method is common in China! Since we first published this recipe over 10 years ago, this smashing method has spread across the English speaking internet as well. It really does create a nice texture. Smashing and opening up the cucumbers also means that they will release a lot of water once you add the dressing the salt in the dressing draws out liquid .

1-chunk_13_3077079764920713113.chunk_text: Smashing and opening up the cucumbers also means that they will release a lot of water once you add the dressing the salt in the dressing draws out liquid . So make sure you dress the salad right before serving! Don’t let it sit around too long, or the dressing will start to dilute. Asian Cucumber Salad: Recipe Instructions

1-chunk_14_-4694859541707221284.chunk_text: Asian Cucumber Salad: Recipe Instructions Make the salad dressing by combining the salt, sugar, sesame oil https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#sesame-oil), light soy sauce https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/), and rice vinegar https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#rice-vinegar). Stir until the sugar and salt are completely dissolved. Wash the cucumbers and pat them dry with a clean towel. On a cutting board, lay a large knife https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to/chinese-cooking-tools/#cleaver) flat against the cucumber, and smash it lightly with your other hand.

1-chunk_15_3366251033018124588.chunk_text:
On a cutting board, lay a large knife https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to/chinese-cooking-tools/#cleaver) flat against the cucumber, and smash it lightly with your other hand. The cucumber should crack open and smash into four sections.
! Image 3: Chinese cucumber salad blob:http://localhost/959adaf9159bdd7d987f52b44327304c) Repeat along its full length.

1-chunk_16_1270524466125816030.chunk_text:
Repeat along its full length. Once the whole cucumber is completely open usually into 4 long sectional pieces , cut it on a 45 degree angle into bite sized pieces.
! Image 4 blob:http://localhost/80bce10e1835ce620572c60c7e37d681) NOTE!

1-chunk_17_-1332704331432948400.chunk_text: NOTE! See Kaitlin’s recipe for homemade chili oil https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to-make-chili-oil/), which is what we always use when we make Cucumber Salad. If you prefer to omit the chili oil, heat up a tablespoon of oil in a pan and drizzle it over the cucumber. Seems weird, but in Chinese cooking, uncooked vs.

1-chunk_18_5619116160159549942.chunk_text:
Seems weird, but in Chinese cooking, uncooked vs. cooked oil have different flavors and are treated as such! In a large bowl, mix the cut cucumber with the prepared dressing, garlic https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#garlic) and chili oil https://thewoksoflife.com/how-to-make-chili-oil/) or cooked plain oil , and toss it well. Serve, garnished with toasted sesame seeds https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#sesame-seeds) and cilantro https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#cilantro).
!

1-chunk_19_-1713059248174136686.chunk_text:
Serve, garnished with toasted sesame seeds https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#sesame-seeds) and cilantro https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#cilantro).

Bill and I also do a taste test at the end!

1-chunk_21_-8104983567898936302.chunk_text: Bill and I also do a taste test at the end! To stay healthy and keep cool this summer, check out some of our other delicious salads https://thewoksoflife.com/category/recipes/salads/ "Salads" . Recipe Prep: 10 minutes

1-chunk_22_1925911990423355092.chunk_text: Prep: 10 minutes Total: 10 minutes ▢ 1 1. 5 pounds seedless cucumbers about 2 English cucumbers

1-chunk_23_-4500977724483906287.chunk_text: 5 pounds seedless cucumbers about 2 English cucumbers ▢ 1 teaspoon salt https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-spices-condiments/#salt) ▢ 2 1/2 teaspoons sugar ▢ 2 teaspoons sesame oil https://thewoksoflife.com/sesame-oil/)

1-chunk_24_-2659760656424732669.chunk_text: ▢ 2 teaspoons sesame oil https://thewoksoflife.com/sesame-oil/) ▢ 3 teaspoons light soy sauce https://thewoksoflife.com/soy-sauce/) ▢ 1 1/2 tablespoons rice vinegar https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-sauces-vinegars-oils/#rice-vinegar) ▢ 2 4 cloves garlic https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#garlic) finely chopped

1-chunk_25_1587783475441499607.chunk_text: ▢ 2 4 cloves garlic https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#garlic) finely chopped ▢ 1 2 teaspoons chili oil https://thewoksoflife.com/2015/08/how-to-make-chili-oil/)(optional) ▢ 2 teaspoons toasted sesame seeds https://thewoksoflife.com/sesame-seeds/) ▢ 1/4 cup chopped cilantro https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#cilantro)

1-chunk_26_-8284021271032820190.chunk_text: ▢ 1/4 cup chopped cilantro https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-chives-scallions-aromatics-peppers/#cilantro) Wash the cucumbers and pat them dry with a clean towel. Make the salad dressing by combining the salt, sugar, sesame oil, light soy sauce, and rice vinegar. Stir until the sugar and salt are completely dissolved.

1-chunk_27_4806104452239277102.chunk_text: Stir until the sugar and salt are completely dissolved. Set aside. On a cutting board, lay a large knife flat against the cucumber, and smash it lightly with your other hand. The cucumber should crack open and smash into four sections.

1-chunk_28_-7380991805103552564.chunk_text: The cucumber should crack open and smash into four sections. Repeat along its full length. Once the whole cucumber is completely open usually into 4 long sectional pieces , cut it at a 45 degree angle into bite sized pieces. In a large bowl, mix the cut cucumber with the prepared dressing, garlic and chili oil.

1-chunk_29_-6365042211964115052.chunk_text: In a large bowl, mix the cut cucumber with the prepared dressing, garlic and chili oil. Toss it well. Serve, garnished with sesame seeds and cilantro. Note: if you prefer to omit the chili oil, heat up a tablespoon of oil in a pan and drizzle it over the cucumber.

1-chunk_30_-331920464472635019.chunk_text: Note: if you prefer to omit the chili oil, heat up a tablespoon of oil in a pan and drizzle it over the cucumber. Seems weird, but in Chinese cooking, uncooked vs. cooked oil have different flavors and are treated as such!
